ThingDef.Name: STAMM_RA
ThingDef.label: Stamm-Saurer M1913
ThingDef.description: The Stamm-Saurer M1913 was a prototype Swiss semi auto rifle predating WW1.

ThingDef.Name: FARQUHAR
ThingDef.label: Farquhar-Hill M1918
ThingDef.description: The Farquhar-Hill M1918 was a British self loading rifle adopted as the "Rifle. .303 inch, Pattern 1918". It didn't see any notable combat service.

ThingDef.Name: FEG_PT
ThingDef.label: Frommer FÉG Self-Loader
ThingDef.description: The Frommer Self-Loader was a prototype Hungarian Semi-Auto rifle. Not much is known about this gun.

ThingDef.Name: GUN_LUGERRIFLE
ThingDef.label: Luger M1906
ThingDef.description: A scaled up Luger pistol chambered in 7.92mm Mauser, It's a pre-WW1 self loader design.

ThingDef.Name: GUN_RHEINMETALL
ThingDef.label: Rheinmetall M1928
ThingDef.description: Designed by Karl Heinemann, a Swiss gun maker, designed this side loading toggle locked rifle to be tested by the US Ordnance department in the late 1920s.

ThingDef.Name: Meunier
ThingDef.label: Meunier A6
ThingDef.description: The Meunier A6 was a French adopted rifle predating WW1. It never saw any substantial service as when war were declared, the project was mostly cancelled.

ThingDef.Name: GRIFFITHSWOODGATE
ThingDef.label: Griffiths-Woodgate
ThingDef.description: The Griffiths-Woodgate rifle was one of the first Self-Loading rifles ever conceived. It used .303 Ammo and it was made in the 1890s.

ThingDef.Name: MONDRAGON
ThingDef.label: Mondrágon M1917
ThingDef.description: The Mondrágon M1917 was a Swiss/Mexican self loader chambered for 7.92mm Mauser after Mexico cancelled their contract with SIG for Mondrágon M1908 rifles. Therefore SIG sold the remaining ones to Germany.

ThingDef.Name: SELBSTLADER1916
ThingDef.label: Mauser Selbstlader 1916 Infantry
ThingDef.description: The Selbstlader Infantry was an attempt by Mauser to get a wide spread adoption of a Self loading rifle for the German Imperial Army. Though it's complex design made the gun unusuable in trench fighting conditions.

ThingDef.Name: ROSSSEMIAUTORIFLE
ThingDef.label: Ross Semiauto Prototype
ThingDef.description: The “Ross” Semiauto Prototype Rifle is a truly forgotten weapon. Almost nothing is known about this firearm. Except it uses Ross Rifle furniture and a Ross Rifle M1910 magazine.

ThingDef.Name: STENDEBACH
ThingDef.label: Stendebach M1936
ThingDef.description: The Stendebach M1936 was a pre-WW2 design that was captured by the Americans on the end of WW2. Only 2 are known to exist today. Unfortunately the guns are incomplete and RimWorld gunsmiths had to improvise with aluminum parts.

ThingDef.Name: HOLUB
ThingDef.label: Holub Light Rifle
ThingDef.description: The Holub was a full-auto 5 round capacity Carbine/LMG hybrid made in the 1920s in Czechoslovakia.

ThingDef.Name: SJOGRENKARABINER
ThingDef.label: Sjögren Karabiner M1894
ThingDef.description: The Sjögren M1894 was the carbine version of the later Sjögren Shotgun.

ThingDef.Name: BJORGUMSL
ThingDef.label: Bjorgum M/1916
ThingDef.description: The Bjorgum was a Swedish made self-loading rifle for Norway. When Norway refused it, it was rechambered in .303 for the British.

ThingDef.Name: MADSEN1896
ThingDef.label: Madsen M1896 Flaadens Rekylgevær
ThingDef.description: The Madsen M1896 was the first Self-loading rifle to be used in any military on the world. The Danish bought 40-50 rifles to be used as coastal defense guns.

ThingDef.Name: BANGM1927
ThingDef.label: Bang M1927
ThingDef.description: The Bang M1927 was a British trials rifle invented by the Danish.

ThingDef.Name: MANNLICHERM1901/04
ThingDef.label: Mannlicher M1901/04 Carbine
ThingDef.description: The Mannlicher M1901/04 was a carbine based on the M1896 Pistol designed by Mannlicher.

ThingDef.Name: PIEPERCARBINE
ThingDef.label: Pieper Model 1893 Revolving Carbine
ThingDef.description: The weapon was developed in the late 1890s by Pieper in Belgium. It is only known to have be used by the Mexican Rural Police. Very few were made and it is very highly valued by collectors because of that.

ThingDef.Name: ZH29
ThingDef.label: ZH-29
ThingDef.description: The ZH-29 was a Czech designed semi-auto rifle chambering 7x92mm Mauser. It was primarily used in Ethiopia and in China.

ThingDef.Name: STEYRM1911
ThingDef.label: Steyr M1911 Self-Loader
ThingDef.description: The Steyr Self-Loader was a prototype Semi-Auto rifle made in Austria-Hungary before WW1. It didn't get adopted because of Austrian worries about the tensions and the possibility of a new war.

ThingDef.Name: GENERALLIUSEMI
ThingDef.label: General Liu (Semi-Auto mode)
ThingDef.description: The General Liu was a chinese Semi-auto rifle. Almost adopted and mass produced, sadly it's designer had a stroke before being able to start production. This rifle also featured a selectable fire-mode in which you could switch it into a Straight-pull bolt action.

ThingDef.Name: MAS191821
ThingDef.label: MAS 1918/21
ThingDef.description: The MAS 1918/21 was an attempt by Manufacture d'Armes de Saint-Étienne to make an Semi-automatic rifle for the French army.

ThingDef.Name: RSC1918
ThingDef.label: RSC Mle 1918
ThingDef.description: The RSC 1918 was the updated Carbine version of the original M1917 rifle.

ThingDef.Name: BERETTAM1918-30
ThingDef.label: Beretta M1918-30
ThingDef.description: Starting in 1930, Beretta re-purposed many surplus M1918s into semi-automatic carbines known as the M1918/30.

ThingDef.Name: BERT31
ThingDef.label: Beretta Mod. 1931
ThingDef.description: Designed by Tullio Marengoni in 1931, the rifle was developed as a response to the Italian Army looking for a self-loading rifle

ThingDef.Name: SCOTTIMODX
ThingDef.label: Scotti Modello X
ThingDef.description: The Scotti Modello X was an experimental Italian semiauto design from the 30s. It was introduced in 1934 with a total of 250 made for trials.

ThingDef.Name: SCOTTICARBINE
ThingDef.label: Scotti SLR Carbine
ThingDef.description: The Scotti SLR is the Semi-automatic version of the Scotti Naval rifle.

ThingDef.Name: CEIRIGOTTI
ThingDef.label: Cei-Rigotti
ThingDef.description: The Cei-Rigotti was an Italian prototype self-loading rifle designed by Amerigo Cei-Rigotti. Notably featuring a select-fire function, the Cei-Rigotti was one of the first fully-automatic rifles in history.

ThingDef.Name: MOSQUETON
ThingDef.label: Mosquetón CB-51
ThingDef.description: This particular rifle, designated Mosqueton CB-51, was one of many intermediate cartridge experiments. It retained the furniture and general appearance of a Mauser bolt action short rifle, but used a long stroke gas piston and rotating bolt in a self-loading action. Only 12 of these were made.

ThingDef.Name: C98
ThingDef.label: Mauser C98 Selbstladegewehr
ThingDef.description: The C98 was Paul Mauser's initial self-loading military rifle design and first patented in Germany in 1898, it was test firing this design that cost Mauser the sight of his right eye during a breech explosion.

ThingDef.Name: HAGEN
ThingDef.label: Hagen Self-Loading rifle
ThingDef.description: The Hagen was a Norwegian prototype Semi-Automatic rifle that was tested by the French before WW1.

ThingDef.Name: HUNNESHAGENSLR
ThingDef.label: Hunneshagen M1924 Selbstladegewehr
ThingDef.description: The Hunneshagen M1924 was the early version of the later Hunneshagen semi-auto rifle. A very similar rifle made by Siemens was produced but no images remain.

ThingDef.Name: WFAK47
ThingDef.label: W+F AK-47
ThingDef.description: The W+F AK47 is an update to their latter AK-44 rifle. This gun is completely based on the SVT-40 Soviet rifle, but using Swiss K31 Furniture.

ThingDef.Name: WF1943
ThingDef.label: Selbstladekarabiner W+F 43
ThingDef.description: The W+F 43 was a prototype Semi-automatic rifle conversion of the K31 rifle. This rifle came with an integrated sniper scope.
